Module nl.naturalis.common
Package nl.naturalis.common.check

Class Check<T,​E extends Exception>

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.naturalis.common.check.Check<T,​E>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of the object being checked
    E - The type of exception thrown if a test fails
    public abstract class Check<T,​E extends Exception>
extends Object
    Facilitates the validation of arguments and object state. Validating object state and array indices happens through a single public static method. Validation of arguments happens by means of an actual instance of the Check class. You obtain an instance through one of the static factory methods. For example: 

     this.numChairs = Check.that(numChairs).is(notNegative()).is(lte(), 10).is(even()).ok();

    Common checks

    The CommonChecks class contains a number of common checks for arguments. These are already associated with short, informative error messages, so you don't have to invent them yourself. For example: 

     Check.that(numChairs, "numChairs").is(gte(), 2);
 // "numChairs must be >= 2 (was 0)"

    Checking argument properties

    A Check object lets you check not just arguments but also argument properties. For example: 

     Check.notNull(name, "name").has(String::length, "length", gte(), 10);
 Check.notNull(employee, "employee").has(Employee::getAge, "age", lt(), 50);
 Check.notNull(intArray, "intArray").has(Array::getLength, "length", even());
 Check.notNull(employees, "employees").has(Collection::size, "size", gte(), 100);

    The CommonGetters class defines some common getters that you can use for conciseness: 

     Check.notNull(name, "name").has(strlen(), gte(), 10);
 Check.notNull(intArray, "intArray").has(length(), even());
 Check.notNull(employees, "employees").has(size(), gte(), 100);

    Lambdas

    Checks are done via the various is(...) and has(...) methods. Generally, the compiler has no problem deciding which of the overloaded methods is targeted. When using lambdas, however, the compiler may run into ambiguities. This will result in a compiler error like: The method has [...] is ambigious for type Check [...]. To resolve this, simply specify the type of the parameters in the lambda: 

     // WILL NOT COMPILE:
 // Check.notNull(employee, "employee").has(Employee::getId, "id", x -> x > 0);
 // WILL COMPILE:
 Check.notNull(employee, "employee").has(Employee::getId, "id", (int x) -> x > 0); // and(IntPredicate)
 Check.notNull(employee, "employee").has(Employee::getId, "id", (Integer x) -> x > 0); // and(Predicate<Integer>)

    Changing the Exception type

    By default an IllegalArgumentException is thrown if an argument fails to pass a test. This can be customized through the static factory methods. For example: 

     this.query = Check.that(query, "query", InvalidQueryException::new)
  .has(QuerySpec::getFrom, "from", nullOr(), 0)
  .has(QuerySpec::getSize, "size", gte(), MIN_BATCH_SIZE)
  .has(QuerySpec::getSize, "size", lt(), MAX_BATCH_SIZE)
  .has(QuerySpec::getSortFields, "sortFields", empty())
  .ok();
    Author:
    Ayco Holleman

        public static void that​(boolean condition,
                        String message,
                        Object... msgArgs)
                 throws IllegalArgumentException
        Generic check method, not related the static factory methods with the same name. Throws an IllegalArgumentException if the provided condition evaluates to false, else does nothing.
        Parameters:
        condition - The condition to evaluate
        message - The error message
        msgArgs - The message arguments
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the condition to evaluate

      • that

        public static <F extends Exception> void that​(boolean condition,
                                              Supplier<F> exceptionSupplier)
                                       throws F extends Exception

        Type Parameters:

        Parameters:

        msgArgs - The String.format message arguments
        Throws:

      • badArgument

        public static Function<String,​IllegalArgumentException> badArgument​(String message,
                                                                          Object... msgArgs)
        Utility method returning an IllegalArgumentException Supplier using the provided message and message arguments to create an exception message. Can be used in various cases as a static import to avoid bloated code: 

         Check.that(foo.equals(bar), () -> new IllegalArgumentException(String.format("%s must equal %s", foo, bar)));
    // versus:
 Check.that(foo.equals(bar), badArgument("%s must equal %s", foo, bar));
        Parameters:
        message - The exception message
        msgArgs - The String.format message arguments
        Returns:
        An IllegalArgumentException Supplier

        Returns the name of the argument being tested.

        The name of the argument being tested

      • has

        public <U> Check<T,​E> has​(Function<T,​U> getter,
                                Predicate<U> test,
                                String message,
                                Object... msgArgs)
                         throws E extends Exception
        Submits a property of the argument to the specified test.
        Type Parameters:
        U - The type of the property
        Parameters:
        getter - A Function which is given the argument as input and which should return the value to be tested
        test - The test
        message - The error message
        msgArgs - The message arguments
        Returns:
        This Check object
        Throws:
        E - If the test fails
        E extends Exception

                     throws E extends Exception

      • has

        public <U,​V> Check<T,​E> has​(Function<T,​U> getter,
                                        String property,
                                        Relation<U,​V> relation,
                                        V relateTo)
                                 throws E extends Exception
        Verifies that there is some relation between a property of the argument and some other value.
        Type Parameters:
        U - The type of the property
        V - The type of the object of the relationship
        Parameters:
        getter - A Function which is given the argument as input and which should return the subject of the relationship
        property - The name of the property
        relation - The relation to verify between subject and object
        relateTo - The object of the relationship
        Returns:
        This Check object
        Throws:
        E - If the specified relation does not exist between subject and object
        E extends Exception

      • ok

        public abstract T ok()
        Returns the argument being tested. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks. For example: 
         int age = Check.notNull(employee, "employee").has(Employee::getAge, "age", lt(), 50).ok().getAge();
        Returns:
        The argument

      • ok

        public <U> U ok​(Function<T,​U> transformer)
        Passes the validated argument to the specified Function and returns the value computed by the Function. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks.
        Type Parameters:
        U - The type of the returned value
        Parameters:
        transformer - A Function that transforms the argument into some other value
        Returns:
        The value computed by the Function

      • then

        public void then​(Consumer<T> consumer)
        Passes the validated argument to a Consumer to be processed safely. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks.
        Parameters:
        consumer - The Consumer

      • intValue

        public abstract int intValue()
                      throws E extends Exception
        Returns the argument being tested as an int. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks. If the argument being tested actually is an int (rather than an Integer), this method saves the cost of a boxing-unboxing round trip incurred by ok().
        Returns:
        The argument cast or converted to an int
        Throws:
        E extends Exception
        See Also:
        NumberMethods.fitsInto(Number, Class)

      • intValue

        public <U> U intValue​(IntFunction<U> transformer)
               throws E extends Exception
        Passes the validated argument to the specified Function and returns the value computed by the Function. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks.
        Parameters:
        transformer - An IntFunction that transforms the argument into some other value
        Throws:
        E extends Exception
